questions.question: Primary purpose of a PR template is to:
options: Capture context, scope, risk, and test plan to guide reviewers
Enforce stylistic preferences strictly
Replace testing entirely with reviewer judgment
Increase PR size to reduce review frequency
questions.additionalContext: Structured templates improve clarity and reduce back–and–forth by front–loading essential context.

questions.question: Risk labels (e.g., low/medium/high) are most useful when they:
options: Decorate PRs without any process impact
Route to appropriate reviewers, set SLAs, and tune checklists
Replace automated checks
Discourage contributors from opening PRs
questions.additionalContext: Labels steer routing, response time, and the depth of review; high–risk changes may need synchronous walkthroughs.

questions.question: Non–blocking vs blocking feedback distinction is:
options: Non–blocking comments are style nitpicks only
Blocking comments only apply to code formatting
Non–blocking suggestions come with rationale; blocking is reserved for correctness, risk, or policy
Both terms are interchangeable
questions.additionalContext: Use non–blocking suggestions for improvements; reserve blocking for defects, violations, or material risk.

questions.question: When should a draft PR be used?
options: Only after code is fully complete
When asking for early directional feedback before final polish
To bypass required reviews
To avoid running CI checks
questions.additionalContext: Draft PRs invite early feedback and surface risks sooner without signaling readiness to merge.

questions.question: A core flow metric for PR SLAs is:
options: Lines of code changed
Number of emojis in comments
Percentage of squash merges
Time–to–first–review from PR open
questions.additionalContext: Time to first review predicts cycle time and developer satisfaction; it is a leading indicator for throughput.

questions.question: Effective reviewer checklists focus on:
options: Risk–based items like security, performance budgets, accessibility, error handling
Personal naming preferences
Keyboard layout consistency
Whimsical style changes
questions.additionalContext: Risk–based checklists improve consistency for hot spots and reduce escaped defects.

questions.question: Reviewer assignment best practice for reliability is:
options: Assign at random for all PRs
Assign only senior engineers regardless of domain
Use CODEOWNERS for domain experts plus round–robin backups; escalate by risk label
Always ask the author to self–approve
questions.additionalContext: Owners ensure domain knowledge; backups provide coverage; labels tune routing and speed based on risk.

questions.question: Converting a PR to blocking should happen when:
options: A reviewer prefers a different naming style
Commit messages exceed a line limit
The author asks a question in comments
New information reveals correctness or security risk
questions.additionalContext: Escalate to blocking when risk is material (security, correctness, contracts). Keep preferences non–blocking.

questions.question: Design a PR template structure that improves review quality and speed. Include sections and examples of good content.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Template sections: Context & intent, Scope of change, Risk level & impact, Test plan (manual/automated), Rollout/flag plan, Checklist (security, accessibility, performance, errors). Provide examples for each so submitters know what “good” looks like.

questions.question: Set PR review SLAs for a medium–sized team. Include routing by risk label, expectations for time–to–first–review, and etiquette for non–blocking vs blocking comments.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Route low–risk PRs via round–robin with a 4–business–hour first–review SLA; medium risk to owners within 1 business day; high risk requires owner + synchronous walkthrough within 1 business day. Non–blocking feedback includes rationale and alternatives; blocking is reserved for correctness, security, or policy violations. Track SLA adherence and change failure rate across sprints.
